messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 24, 2024 - July 30, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-07-31T21:25:34Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-07-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-07-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240731-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 33 M-class flares, 3 O-type CMEs, and 21 C-type CMEs (see details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-07-26T20:48Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-07-29T13:38Z, Kp index 6-8 (moderate to severe) 
                                       (see notification 20240727-AL-004).

2024-07-26T21:24Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-07-29T13:38Z, Kp index 6-8 (moderate to severe) 
                                       (see notification 20240727-AL-004).

2024-07-27T06:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-29T13:38Z, Kp index 6-8 (moderate to severe)
                                       (see notification 20240727-AL-004).

---The combined arrival of the above 3 CMEs may have been detected at L1 around 2024-07-29T23:20Z (see notification 20240730-AL-001).

2024-07-28T02:24Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-31T05:15Z, Kp index 5-7 (minor to strong)
                                       (see notification 20240728-AL-006).

2024-07-28T12:12Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-31T05:15Z, Kp index 5-7 (minor to strong)
                                       (see notification 20240728-AL-006).

2024-07-28T14:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-07-31T05:15Z, Kp index 5-7 (minor to strong)
                                       (see notification 20240728-AL-006).

---The combined arrival of the above 3 CMEs may have been detected at L1 around 2024-07-31T13:46Z (see notification 20240731-AL-007). Analysis is ongoing.

2024-07-29T02:00Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-01T16:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240729-AL-007).

2024-07-29T02:12Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-01T16:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240729-AL-007).

2024-07-29T13:25Z   NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-08-01T16:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240729-AL-007).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-07-24T08:23Z   Mars at 2024-07-28T16:00Z (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-26T17:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-26T16:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2024-07-27T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240724-AL-002).
2024-07-24T17:36Z   Mars at 2024-07-28T10:59Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-26T17:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2024-07-27T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240724-AL-003).
2024-07-24T18:36Z   Mars at 2024-07-28T10:59Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-26T17:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2024-07-27T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240724-AL-003).
2024-07-25T00:24Z   Psyche at 2024-07-31T08:00Z (glancing blow) and Solar Orbiter at 2024-07-28T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240725-AL-001).
2024-07-26T20:48Z   Lucy at 2024-07-30T19:43Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-28T14:01Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-29T08:51Z, and Mars at 2024-08-01T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240727-AL-004).
2024-07-26T21:24Z   Lucy at 2024-07-30T19:43Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-28T14:01Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-29T08:51Z, and Mars at 2024-08-01T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240727-AL-004).
2024-07-27T04:48Z   Psyche at 2024-08-01T12:53Z (see notification 20240727-AL-002).
2024-07-27T06:36Z   Lucy at 2024-07-30T19:43Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-28T14:01Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-29T08:51Z, and Mars at 2024-08-01T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240727-AL-004).
2024-07-28T02:24Z   Lucy at 2024-08-01T13:16Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-30T02:58Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-30T20:57Z, and Mars at 2024-08-02T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240728-AL-006).
2024-07-28T12:12Z   Lucy at 2024-08-01T13:16Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-30T02:58Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-30T20:57Z, and Mars at 2024-08-02T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240728-AL-006).
2024-07-28T14:36Z   Lucy at 2024-08-01T13:16Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-30T02:58Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-30T20:57Z, and Mars at 2024-08-02T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240728-AL-006).
2024-07-29T02:00Z  STEREO A at 2024-08-01T07:25Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-31T06:00Z (minor impact), and Mars at 2024-08-02T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240729-AL-007).
2024-07-29T02:12Z  STEREO A at 2024-08-01T07:25Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-31T06:00Z (minor impact), and Mars at 2024-08-02T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240729-AL-007).
2024-07-29T13:25Z  STEREO A at 2024-08-01T07:25Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-31T06:00Z (minor impact), and Mars at 2024-08-02T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240729-AL-007).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 during the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-07-30T03:00Z-06:00Z. This enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-07-29T23:20Z which may have been associated with the arrival of the S-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-07-26T15:23Z and C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-07-26T20:48Z, 2024-07-26T21:24Z, and 2024-07-27T06:36Z (see notification 20240730-AL-001). This arrival was detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2024-07-29T19:13Z. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. At the end of the reporting period the energetic electron flux was elevated to about 800 pfu, but subsided to background levels on 2024-07-30. This elevation was likely associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 on 2024-07-25.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-07-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-08-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently twelve numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13764 (S03W44) produced an X-class flare during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk on or around 2024-08-03. Additionally, Active Regions 13762 (S11W84) and 13766 (S07W36) contributed to the majority of M-class flares observed during the reporting period and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk on or around 2024-08-01 and 2024-08-05, respectively. Finally, newly numbered Active Region 13772 (S25E47) produced 2 M-class flares during the reporting period and will likely continue to produce significant flaring activity as it traverses the Earth-facing disk.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between below minor to strong levels during the outlook period. Enhancement in geomagnetic activity may be observed on 2024-07-31 due to the ongoing arrival of the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-07-28T02:24Z, 2024-07-28T12:12Z, and 2024-07-28T14:36Z and/or around 2024-08-01 due to possible glancing blow arrivals from the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-07-29T02:00Z, 2024-07-29T02:12Z, and 2024-07-29T13:25Z described above.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

##

## Message ID: 20240731-AL-010
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event forecasted near L1 orbit by the HESPERIA RELeASE model starting at 2024-07-31T20:10Z. The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels may exceed 10^(-1) pfu/MeV within next few hours.

NASA spacecraft at the L1 and near-Earth orbits can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-07-31T20:10:00-SEP-002.

## Notes: 

This SEP event (2024-07-31T20:10:00-SEP-002) is associated with M5.3 flare from AR 3768 (S15W73) with ID 2024-07-31T18:05:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-07-31T18:37Z (see notifications 20240731-AL-008, 20240731-AL-009).

## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-07-31T13:46Z. 

The shock may be caused by the combined arrival of CME with ID 2024-07-28T02:24:00-CME-001, CME with ID 2024-07-28T12:12:00-CME-001, and CME with ID 2024-07-28T14:36:00-CME-001 (see notification 20240728-AL-006), and possibly the arrival of CME with ID 2024-07-27T11:12:00-CME-001. Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm expected.

Activity ID: 2024-07-31T13:46:00-IPS-001.

## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2024-07-31T07:12:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240731-AL-003). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars, Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Mars at 2024-08-03T15:04Z and the flank may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2024-08-02T14:00Z and STEREO A at 2024-08-02T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

CME parameters are (O-type):

Start time of the event: 2024-07-31T07:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~1310 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 25 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 60/16 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-07-31T07:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect STEREO A, Parker Solar Probe (minor impact), and Mars (glancing blow). The combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach STEREO A at 2024-08-01T07:25Z and may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-31T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicates that the CMEs may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 22 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 9 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-07-19T21:36Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-07-23T02:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240720-AL-001).

2024-07-19T22:24Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-07-23T02:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240720-AL-001).

2024-07-21T16:48Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-07-24T16:11Z, Kp index 4-6 (below minor to moderate) 
                                       (see notification 20240721-AL-003).

The combined arrival of the three CMEs listed above may have been detected at L1 by DSCOVR/ACE around 2024-07-23T19:48Z (see notification 20240723-AL-009). Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-07-17T19:00Z   Psyche at 2024-07-26T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240718-AL-001).
2024-07-19T21:36Z   Lucy at 2024-07-24T10:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-21T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240720-AL-001).
2024-07-19T22:24Z   Lucy at 2024-07-24T10:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-21T12:00Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-07-22T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240720-AL-001).
2024-07-20T23:24Z   Psyche at 2024-07-28T16:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240721-AL-002).
2024-07-21T04:24Z   Mars at 2024-07-25T08:00Z (minor impact), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-23T16:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240721-AL-001).
2024-07-21T11:00Z   Mars at 2024-07-26T00:00Z (glancing blow).
2024-07-21T16:48Z   Lucy at 2024-07-25T16:37Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-07-23T12:55Z, STEREO A at 2024-07-24T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240721-AL-003).
2024-07-23T00:23Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-07-24T12:43Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-07-24T10:44Z, Juno at 2024-08-09T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240723-AL-008).
2024-07-23T14:48Z   Lucy at 2024-07-27T17:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240724-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

A solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A during the reporting period. At SOHO, the fluxes of the 15.8-39.8 MeV and 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-07-23T02:32Z and 2024-07-23T02:28Z, respectively (see notification 20240723-AL-007).  At GOES, the integral flux of the > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-07-23T03:00Z (see notifications 20240723-AL-005, 20240723-AL-006) and the integral flux of the > 100 MeV protons exceeded 1 pfu starting at 2024-07-23T02:05Z (see notifications 20240723-AL-003, 20240723-AL-004). At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-07-23T01:20Z (see notifications 20240723-AL-001, 20240723-AL-002). This solar energetic particle event was associated with a far-sided O-type halo CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2024-07-23T00:23Z (see notification 20240723-AL-008). The enhanced particle environment at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A began to subside towards background levels during the latter part of 2024-07-23.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this reporting period due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-07-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-07-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently 10 numbered active regions on the Earth-facing disk. Currently, the most magnetically complex active regions are Active Regions 13751 and 13762. Active Region 13751 (S08W67) produced 5 of the M-class flares observed during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit additional M-class flaring before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-07-27. Active Region 13762 (S12E13) produced 3 of the M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit M-class flaring activity as it traverses the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-07-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-07-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently 17 numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13738 has rotated off the west limb of the Earth-facing disk early on 2024-07-17, but may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity visible just beyond the western limb until 2024-07-18.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between below minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. An enhancement in geomagnetic activity may be observed on or around 2024-07-19 and 2024-07-20 due to the possible combined arrival of the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-07-16T23:12Z and 2024-07-16T23:23Z, as well as the separate, possible glancing blow arrival of S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-07-16T08:48Z. Additionally, a large high-latitude coronal hole currently centered around N35W17 and longitudinally spanning E08 to W42 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-07-17 to 2024-07-18.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2024-07-03T17:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the arrival of the CME with ID 2024-06-25T05:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20240625-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2024-06-28T09:09Z (see notification 20240628-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-07-03T17:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

The CME arrival is associated with the severe geomagnetic storm with ID 2024-06-28T09:00:00-GST-001 with one synoptic period of Kp = 7.67 (see notifications 20240628-AL-002, 20240628-AL-003, 20240628-AL-004, 20240628-AL-005). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-06-28T17:07Z (see notifications 20240628-AL-006, 20240628-AL-007).
